cultural_sites.name: Rajgad Fort
cultural_sites.description: Rajgad Fort, the capital of the Maratha Empire under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj for over two decades, is known for its strategic importance, stunning architecture, and panoramic views of the Sahyadri mountain range.

cultural_sites.name: Ajanta Caves
cultural_sites.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Ajanta Caves are rock-cut Buddhist cave monuments dating from the 2nd century BCE to about 480 CE.

cultural_sites.name: Ellora Caves
cultural_sites.description: The Ellora Caves are one of the largest rock-cut monastery-temple cave complexes in the world, featuring artwork dating from the 600-1000 CE period.

cultural_sites.name: Gateway of India
cultural_sites.description: A monumental arch built in the early 20th century in Mumbai, it is a symbol of the city and one of its most famous landmarks.

cultural_sites.name: Shaniwar Wada
cultural_sites.description: A historical fortification in the city of Pune, built in 1732, it was the seat of the Peshwas of the Maratha Empire until 1818.

cultural_sites.name: Ram Mandir
cultural_sites.description: The Ram Mandir, also known as the Ram Temple, is a significant Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Ram, located in Ayodhya. It is a major site of pilgrimage and cultural importance.

cultural_sites.name: Taj Mahal
cultural_sites.description: One of the Seven Wonders of the World, the Taj Mahal is an ivory-white marble mausoleum on the south bank of the Yamuna river, built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.

cultural_sites.name: Varanasi Ghats
cultural_sites.description: The Ghats of Varanasi are riverfront steps leading to the banks of the River Ganges. They are known for their spiritual significance and religious rituals.

cultural_sites.name: Fatehpur Sikri
cultural_sites.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Fatehpur Sikri is a city founded by Emperor Akbar in 1571, which served as the capital of the Mughal Empire for a short period.

cultural_sites.name: Lucknow Residency
cultural_sites.description: The British Residency is a group of several buildings in a common precinct, the site of a dramatic event during the Indian Rebellion of 1857.

cultural_sites.name: Shankaracharya Temple
cultural_sites.description: An ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, situated on Shankaracharya Hill overlooking the city of Srinagar. It offers panoramic views of the Kashmir Valley.

cultural_sites.name: Mughal Gardens
cultural_sites.description: A collection of beautiful gardens built during the Mughal era, including Shalimar Bagh, Nishat Bagh, and Chashme Shahi. These gardens are renowned for their exquisite layout and floral displays.

cultural_sites.name: Jammu Fort
cultural_sites.description: A historical fort located in the city of Jammu. It served as the residence of the Dogra rulers and features intricate architectural details and panoramic views of the surrounding area.

cultural_sites.name: Vaishno Devi Temple
cultural_sites.description: A highly revered Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Vaishno Devi. It is one of the most visited pilgrimage sites in India, situated on the Trikuta Mountains.

cultural_sites.name: Dal Lake
cultural_sites.description: A large, picturesque lake in Srinagar famous for its houseboats and shikaras (traditional wooden boats). The lake is surrounded by stunning gardens and the Himalayan mountains.

cultural_sites.name: Hemis Monastery
cultural_sites.description: One of the largest and wealthiest Buddhist monasteries in Ladakh, known for its annual Hemis festival and impressive collection of Buddhist artifacts and artworks.

cultural_sites.name: Lal Chowk
cultural_sites.description: A prominent commercial and cultural center in Srinagar. It is known for its vibrant atmosphere, shops, and historical significance.
